Pharrell dressed over a dozen people for tonight’sMet Gala red carpet, many of whom passed through the suite—decked out with trunks, books, artwork, collectibles, and ephemera covered in the signature LV monogram—to get their photos taken in a fully functional content studio built out for the evening. To a soundtrack of Skepta, Jay-Z, Amy Winehouse, and Lauryn Hill, a mix of his longtime friends and collaborators (Pusha T,Future,Henry Taylor) and icons of the new generation (Sabrina Carpenter, Lisa, Doechii) filed in and out ahead of their red carpet departures. In one sweet moment—especially to me, a Virginia Beach native—Pharrell came to check out Pusha’s full ‘fit and give him a round of applause, before getting out of his jeans and pink polo to put on his own look, comprised of a cropped jacket hand-crafted entirely from white pearls. Lisa and Future Malcolm Washington,a Met newbie, was honored to wear a classic Pharrell Williams silhouette for his first time: a double-breasted smoking jacket and flared trousers. “This is such a cool Met to come to, the reason we’re here is so exciting and it’s been personal in my life in a way, so it’s cool to come celebrate Black dandyism.” The director is a longtime fan of fashion, and loves self-expression through all artistic practices. (Washington comes from an art-forward family: His dad, of course, is Denzel.) “My grandfather was the principal of a Black high school. When schools were integrated in the ’60s, he lost his position, but still within it he found so much dignity in how he dressed,” he says. “I always thought that was such a beautiful way to express [that] in how you carry yourself, and to now be here, and get to wear a classic tuxedo by a Black man at an event such as this celebrating that, felt like a wonderful full-circle moment.” Malcolm Washington Malcolm Washington Jeremy Allen White’s another of the LV crew’s Met rookies. “I feel nervous, excited, but good. I feel like I look nice,” he says with a smile. As for his ensemble? “For a couple of months we’ve been piecing it together,” he says, looking over at his stylist Jamie Mizrahi. “We had a lot of reference photos, the pinstripes were something that we found pretty early on in the fabrics, and the suit just got snugger and snugger and sharper and sharper as we went. We wanted to do something kind of period, but also timeless, and just make sure that the tailoring itself was very elegant and angular.” Despite having many friends who have attended the Met, White’s going in cold. “I don’t know what happens in that room, nobody does, I guess, if you haven’t been before, but I am excited to see,” he says. He’s heard about the famous smoking section, where all of the fun allegedly happens. “Well, that’s where I’ll be most of the night,” he deadpans. “I think I might be there the whole time, just kinda hiding.” Jeremy Allen White “I’m really excited, it sounds like it’s going to be beautiful carnage,” saysCallum Turner, who’s also a Met first-timer. He’s heard the rumor about the smoking section, too. “Zoe Kravitz told me yesterday that you’re not allowed to smoke in the bathroom anymore,” he says. He is dressed in a cropped double-breasted blazer that he and Pharrell worked on for a few weeks; when the two crossed paths in the suite, they chatted about a last-minute change that went into Turner’s suit, and both appeared to be pleased with the final result. He’s also wearing a crystal, hand-embroidered tie in the pattern of the Louis Vuitton Damier checks; sparkles are admittedly outside of his comfort zone, but he’s pulling them off. Callum Turner and Pharrell Callum Turner By 5:20 p.m., most of the Louis Vuitton crew was on their way to the carpet, and for the first time, there’s some breathing room to be found at the Mark. There were a few stragglers: Blackpink’s Lisa, a LV brand ambassador, came in after the rush to get her photos taken. Doechii, perhaps the event’s most highly anticipated rookie, was dressed in a tailcoat and waistcoat featuring pearl-encrusted buttons inspired by the wardrobe of the Afro-Caribbean fencing master Julius Soubise, and left the hotel in a box that the Louis Vuitton team had custom made to preserve the surprise. Jeremy Allen White snuck in one last smoke on the auxiliary suite’s balcony in the rain before departing the Mark, taking special care to not mess up his hair. On the way out the door, he double checked (and confirmed to the team) that he had all he needed for the night ahead: phone, cigarettes, lighter.

title: “There’s a Lot of Tension”: Democrats Are Locked In a Generational Fight
article_text: The impending Democratic opening at the top of the House Oversight Committee has reopened rifts between the party establishment and its younger insurgent wing. Back in December, then 74-year-oldGerry Connolly—who was being treated for esophageal cancer—was elected ranking member of the powerful watchdog panel overAlexandria Ocasio-Cortez,the 35-year-old progressive who has emerged as one of the party’s most dynamic stars. The snub seemed, at the time, a reflection of adeeper issuefor Democrats: that the party’s aging old guard was too reluctant to abandon its power, and valued seniority and longevity over the kind of change that Democrats’ 2024 losses seemed to call for. Five months later, withDonald Trumprunning roughshod over democracy, Connollywill be stepping down from his leadership roledue to a reemergence of his cancer. But AOC, who had been said to be considering another run for the Oversight post, ultimately decided against throwing her hat into the ring: “It’s actually clear to me,” shetold reportersMonday, “that the underlying dynamics in the caucus have not shifted with respect to seniority as much as I think would be necessary.” Ocasio-Cortez’s decision leaves an open lane for other younger Democrats to make a run at the position, includingJasmine Crockett,Maxwell Frost,andRobert Garcia.But it could also make the path for 70-year-old Massachusetts representativeStephen Lynch—who has been endorsed by Connolly and some other more establishment figures—all the clearer. To be sure, the divide isn’t just about age, as Pennsylvania progressiveSummer Lee—one of the younger members of the Oversight Committee—told me. “I know some old folks who got fire still, and maybe are more ideologically connected to me,” the 37-year-old said. But, Lee suggested, some of the younger Democrats are better able to rise up to these “unprecedented times” because they are able to see them more clearly, without the fog of nostalgia. “There are, quite frankly, people who were here at a time when bipartisanship existed. I’ve never seen it. There are people who were here before the Tea Party and before Trump as a politician existed, and they have a nostalgia for the institution as it existed then,” Lee said. But “we are in times that take different tactics.” The fight over Oversight is, of course, a proxy fight for a bigger battle among Democrats. Many of its leaders have faced criticism—within the conference and among the base—for taking a perhapstoo careful,sometimes anemic,occasionally helplessapproach to Trump’s all-out assault on America’s democratic system. Some have downplayed interparty divides: RepresentativeWesley Bell,a 50-year-old Oversight member, told me that any differences among Democrats are “boutique” issues compared with the unified front they are presenting against the Trump administration. “I think there’s a great dynamic of young people with energy and bringing a different perspective, but then also folks who are veterans, who have the experience and wisdom,” Bell said. “I think Democrats are doing everything that we possibly can to push back.” But the base—already frustrated with a party that, in sticking with a senescentJoe Bidenlast year until it was too late, has lost two out of the last three elections to Trump—has shown an appetite for a more aggressive approach to fighting the current administration: “We don’t need [an Oversight leader]…who’s going to be sending, like, strongly worded letters,” saidSantiago Mayer,founder of Voters of Tomorrow, the Democratic-aligned Gen Z political group. “I think we’re now in a moment where we need that energy and we need that fight.” There have been some signs of a changing of the Democratic guard; just in the past two weeks, two prominent lawmakers—SenatorDick Durbin, the minority whip, and fellow IllinoisanJan Schakowsky,who has served in the House since 1999—announced that they would not seek reelection, with both 80-year-olds citing a desire to pass the torch. Meanwhile, a growing number of long-serving members are expected toface primary fightsfrom younger challengers—a movement that has the backing ofDavid Hogg,a 25-year-old vice chair of the Democratic National Committee. (Hogg’s active support of primary challenges to incumbent Democrats has been controversial, drawing a rebuke from DNC ChairKen Martin:“No DNC officer should ever attempt to influence the outcome of a primary election, whether on behalf of an incumbent or a challenger,” hesaidlast month.) At the very least, Lee suggested to me, there is a “more robust conversation” underway about the party’s leadership and approach. The question is what that conversation will mean for Oversight, where the next leader will be tasked with bringing together what Lee called a “constellation” of stars working to provide some check on Trump: “There’s a lot of tension between what direction we’re going in” as a party, Lee told me. “The Oversight Committee obviously epitomizes that.” See All the Fashion, Outfits, and Looks From the2025 Met Gala Red Carpet Hawk TuahOpens Up About Her Crypto Scandal Plus, Who MadeVF’s Met GalaBest-Dressed List? title: Emma Chamberlain Wore Two Courrèges Looks for One Very Long Day at the Met Gala 2025
article_text: Emma Chamberlainis certainly no stranger to theMet Gala: When she hit theMet Gala red carpeton Monday, it was her fifth consecutive year both attending and acting as a host forVogue’s livestream. It means she knows the ins and outs of fashion’s biggest night, and talks to pretty much every A-lister who makes the event’s ultra-exclusive invite list. Met Monday begins at 6:30 a.m. and ends well past midnight for Chamberlain, and that’s after weeks of beauty prep and two days of intensive final interview research once the official guest list is shared with her. Chamberlain’s Met Gala 2025 look needed to both fit the high-fashion billandbe practical enough to work in. “It’s definitely my longest day of the whole year, that’s for sure,” she toldVanity Fairfrom her hotel room ahead of her whirlwind Met Gala. This year, she reached for two bespoke ensembles by French brand Courrèges, the house’s first time dressing a Met attendee under artistic directorNicolas Di Felice.The looks are related, and both referenced the night’s Tailored for You dress code celebrating the exhibit “Superfine: Tailoring Black Style.” For her red-carpet moment early in the night, Chamberlain opted for a hand-embroidered navy pinstripe crepe dress, with a suiting-inspired deconstructed silhouette, open back, and matching tulle tights and gloves, with hand-stitched pinstripe detailing. Then, working with stylistJared Ellnerand Courrèges, she changed into a look that was designed to appear as if she could have been wearing it under her longer red-carpet look, a navy crepe miniskirt, also hand-embroidered, and an asymmetrical white cady shirt, paired with low heels, a must for the long hours Chamberlain spends standing through the night. Chamberlain explained that what started as a “why choose” moment a few years ago—she had the choice of the same Miu Miu look in blue and black and decided to wear both—has since turned into a (very practical) tradition that she cherishes. “There’s no risk of fashion disaster, like a boob coming out or something,” she said of her second look. “Whereas, on the carpet, there is usually a risk of that. These looks are so finicky, so the carpet look is definitely not something I could wear all night. There’s a long train, there’s this and there’s that. Changing into another look has ended up being really special, so that, you know, Jared and I, and whoever we’re working with, can actually have a full moment on the carpet and not cut it short because I’m going and doing the interviews. This is, like, our sport, you know? Like, we love this shit, right? We want to do it to the fullest.” Translating the carpet look to the interview ’fit is, she said, “mainly just about [finding] something that I can move in that’s reminiscent of the carpet look, worn with some sort of comfortable shoe.” Collaborating with Courrèges, she said, was a dream come true after she and Ellner attended the brand’s show for the first time in Paris last year. She called it “our absolute favorite of the season, the one that we were just raving about for, like, weeks and weeks after.” Di Felice, in an email, mirrored the sentiment. “For our very first appearance at the Met Gala, I really enjoyed collaborating with Emma on these looks,” he said. “We have a lot of common values: She is forward-thinking, free-spirited, with a strong fashion sense.” “We were floored, like, it wassomy style on a personal level,” Chamberlain continued. “A lot of times, we go to shows and it might not necessarily be our personal style, but we’re watching art happen, that sort of thing. But this was, like, so me.” Vintage jewelry, watches, and eyeglasses sourced from eBay completed the suite of looks, which she said “could not be more tailored for me.” As a bonus, those vintage bits and bobs are hers now. “The fact that I get to keep it, like, that’s never happened. I’m always giving everything back, which is like, fine, but it’s, like, a million-dollar necklace? That’s not mine. I’m giving that back.” Returning borrowed jewels, she said, is “such a relief. I get so stressed out. There’s security, it’s a crazy thing. So this is a chill year with accessories in a way that’s very fun.” Asked if she has a sartorial security blanket for red carpets, like a certain lipstick, or a color she finds herself gravitating to over and over, Chamberlain paused for a moment to think. “I have no security blankets when it comes to fashion,” she answered. “To be honest, I think my security blanket is my brain, it’s who I am. It’s my soul and my spirit that’s always with me, and my taste and my fashion philosophies, thoughts that are constantly changing.” She said that she tries not to go obsessively deep into the people she’ll be interviewing, because she wants to maintain a level of curiosity that keeps things fresh and exciting for the viewers. Fashion-wise, “Clothes in general are a security blanket for me, and the choices that I make specifically for that event are, you know, what sort of makes me feel safe and like me?” Another Met Gala essential: “My boring-ass cream Stanley cup.” (Chamberlain admits she is aggressively anti-rhinestone and won’t zhuzh her water bottle.) “I’m usually so dehydrated during the Met, because I don’t drink water when I travel,” she explained. “But this year, no excuses. I got the Stanley cup.” She called her Met Gala experiences “chaotic,” this year’s beginning a few weeks ago with a facial that “popped all my zits” after an unexpected breakout, and in more recent days fresh color and a trim for her platinum pixie cut, a self-administered gel manicure (“They’re actually in really good shape, and they match the outfit. And I’m wearing gloves. So I was like, ‘perfect,’” she said), more facials, and a day-of lymphatic massage. This, amidst the flash cards and research, Chamberlain at the center of a swirl of people. “It’s amazing how many people are involved in this process,” she said. “It’s always very humbling for me, it’s a bit challenging for me at times, because I feel almost a level of guilt—there are so many people who are putting so much love and time and effort into this look. I’m a canvas for so many different people. It’s not just about me.” “It’s, like, insane. There’s so many people loving on me, and every year, it feels like my birthday. It feels more like my birthday than my birthday does.” Of course, due to her red-carpet duties, Chamberlain has a different experience of the evening than all the other attendees who also get the glam treatment, though “it’s all I’ve ever known this event to be.” “I actually can’t even imagine what it’d be like to go to The Met and not get yanked back and change, and to have it be this sort of hectic thing. And to be honest, I bet that would be delightful,” she said, laughing. “Usually I get in so late and I’m exhausted by that point and hungry. So I’m like, This is awesome! But I’m also eating. Everyone’s dancing, and I’m eating because I literally just had the longest day.” “My experience is very different than everyone else’s, yeah, but I also think that my experience is so rich,” she said. “It’s very hectic, it’s very chaotic, but also, that’s what I love about it. And it’s all I know.” Accessories: Vintage sourced from eBayLymphatic: Josie RushingBeauty Sandwich: Ivan PolHair: Sami KnightMakeup: Lilly KeysStylist: Jared EllnerFacialist: Shani DardenHaircut:FrankColor: Anthony Vincent For more from the Met Gala 2025, revisitVanity Fair’s Met Gala 2025 liveblogfor the evening’s highlights includingevery look, thebest-dressed of the night, our experts’ picks for whobest embodied the theme, avideo replay of the red carpet, and more. title: Shaboozey Dares Anyone to Outdo His Custom Turquoise Grill at the Met Gala 2025
article_text: If the last year has been crazy forShaboozey,the Virginia singer known for his hip-hop-inflected country music, who shot to fame in 2024 with his indelible single “A Bar Song (Tipsy),” the last few months have been a whirlwind. In the run-up tothe Met Gala 2025, the artist, born Collins Obinna Chibueze, has been serving up maximalist spins on Westernwear at events including two weekends at Coachella, music festivals and awards shows, and a day at the Kentucky Derby. How can you top all of that for fashion’s biggest night? Two words: turquoise grill. Vanity Faircaught up with the singer as he prepped forthe Met Galawith his stylist,Anastasia Walker.“Me and my team did a great job of just finding something that was bold and daring, but still kind of really just played up to all my features,” he said of the look. “It still has a bit of the stuff that I love and I put into my everyday personal style—and a lot of turquoise.” On Monday night, Shaboozey’s unique mouthpiece was just the cherry on top. He walked the carpet in a customRobert Wunblack moiré suit, which featured chains with 3,100 turquoise beads and 2,900 Swarovski crystal beads in jet black. He topped it off with a few spectacular pieces from David Yurman, including a yellow gold Albion ring with turquoise and diamonds, a gold and diamond signet ring, and silver huggie hoop earrings in pavé diamond. “I just love how it all works together. When I saw the sketches I was like, ‘Man, I haven’t done anything like this before.’ But it came together,” he said of the suit, which blends cowboy touches with a dandy-inspired form. “It’s really quality. It doesn’t feel like it’s just something that’s meant to be worn tonight—it’s got durability. You can tell that a lot of craftsmanship went into making the piece.” Shaboozey has long hada strong sense of his personal styleand a love for vintage, but he said his collaboration with Walker has helped him up the ante now that he’s performing on some of the world’s biggest stages. “We always land on something that’s really just always elevating it. Every look is always just an elevation of the previous thing,” he said. “I was always a vintage guy, and it’s been cool to just be able to put some of my favorite brands into that—just mixing it all together. To create something that I feel like is exactly where I want to be.” As for the stress of making his Met Gala debut, Shaboozey said he would be keeping an eye out for the fellow guests he already considers friends and relying on the systems that have helped him manage a year packed with new experiences. “I think I have a very calm demeanor through it all,” he said. “Never really let anything get to be too much. Just don’t let things get too high, don’t let them get too low. There’s always a next day coming.” As for his fellow guests, he was looking forward to seeing whatColman Domingowas planning to wear and was hoping his look would be just as memorable. “Fashion is definitely a form of art. I’m just really excited to see how people react to what we’re wearing,” he said. “Honestly, I’m really confident in our look. I want to see if anyone out there can outdo it.” See All the Fashion, Outfits, and Looks From the2025 Met Gala Red Carpet Hawk TuahOpens Up About Her Crypto Scandal Plus, Who MadeVF’s Met GalaBest-Dressed List? title: Ayo Edebiri, Aimee Lou Wood, Dapper Dan, and More Prep for Fashion’s Biggest Night at Cartier’s Annual Met Gala Pre-Party
article_text: At Cartier’s intimate but glittering—with star power and fine jewelry—annualMet Galapre-party on Monday, everyone had a riveting story to tell. The mood in Bemelmans Bar felt especially energized and festive, as A-list guests readied to celebrate theCostume Institute’s exhibit“Superfine: Tailoring Black Style” while weaving their own narratives of history, family, and personal style through theTailored for You dress code. Ayo Edebiriconsidered the history of dandyism and what it meant to her. “There were just so many different ins: I’m half Nigerian, I grew up in the church, I’m a Black person. I was thinking about [how] the women’s and queer [experience] blends in,” the Met Gala host committee member toldVanity Fair.“So it was all kind of swirling around.” Edebiri’s black leather trench with ribbons flowing down from the pointed cuffs, and white gown with majestically draped coral embellishments by Ferragamo creative directorMaximilian Davisalso paid homage to her Nigerian father’s Edo and Yoruba roots. Edebiri worked with her stylist,Danielle Goldberg,to accessorize with meaningful jewels, like a Clash de Cartier 18k rose gold ring with a cluster of apple green chrysoprase, and an adorable 1966 Cartier Collection yellow gold doggy brooch adorned with rubies. “I love this little dog brooch, partially because I’m missing my dog because he’s back home,” said Edebiri, lifting a sheer-gloved hand to playfully move the head back and forth. “It’s like the cutest thing ever.” The Emmy winner wasn’t the only one whose luxury jewelry choice reminded her of home.Miley Cyrusadorned a custom cropped, croc-embossed leather top and ball gown skirt by Alaïa byPieter Mulierwith a triple-layer, yellow and white gold Cartier Collection necklace from 1988. Miley Cyrus “It’s from the 1980s, so it reminds me a lot of my mom,” said Cyrus of her mother,Tish.“That was her prime, and she will tell you she hasn’t come out of the ’80s yet. I don’t have the heart to tell her that it’s 2025.” TheSomething Beautifulsingeralso considers the Alaïa team to be “like family,” and the fashion house holds sentimental meaning not just for designer Azzedine Alaïa’s collaborations with legend Tina Turner, but for Cyrus herself. “I remember my first big purchase was a perforated Alaïa belt,” said Cyrus. “So now to be able to represent them at The Met, it just feels like it’s a very full circle.” Kelvin Harrison Jr.,who played B.B. King inElvisand the titular 18th-century trailblazing composer and violinist inChevalier,also looked to musical greats to express Black dandyism through his Prada double-breasted suit. “I always wanted to be like a Quincy Jones meets Nat King Cole and that timeless kind of sassy, flamboyant masculinity,” said Harrison, who was styled byMichael Fisher,also pointing toward his tulip-print shirt, which threaded back to his attendance at the 2022 Met Gala with directorBaz Luhrmannand theElviscast. “Austin Butlerhad a really pretty little scarf,” said Harrison of Butler's 2022 look. He similarly undid his shirt’s necktie to showcase four gleaming necklaces, with a 1984 Cartier Collection yellow gold, sapphire, and diamond chain pendant as the centerpiece. “[The necklace] has a little bit of sex appeal to it, but at the same time, there’s something very androgynous about the diamonds and the jewels.” Jon Batiste Upon first spotting Harrison at the bash, Oscar- and Grammy-winning musician extraordinaireJon Batisteyelped in delight. Fun fact: For Batiste’s custom Dunhill tux last year, he took inspiration from Joseph Bologne, Chevalier de Saint Georges, formerly embodied on film by Harrison. “One of my favorite things about the Met Gala is this ability for us to all align on the theme and come together and celebrate something that brought us to this moment,” said Batiste, who was styled byLaw Roach.“Now we’re here together, celebrating the dandyism of our ancestors.” With his custom Tom Ford suit this year, Batiste recognized a Hall of Fame of Black American musicians, including Duke Ellington, Miles Davis, Allen Toussaint, Fats Domino, and Harold Battiste. The delicate white polka dots on Batiste’s double-breasted suit jacket lauded “all of the great conductors,” like band leader Fletcher Henderson, while the billowing material and cut of his trousers saluted the maestros of the ’40s. “It allows you to dance,” said Batiste. “If you can imagine seeing the Mills Brothers, Cab Calloway, Chuck Berry, and Little Richard onstage, and the motion, I wanted that silhouette.” Batiste also paid tribute to before-her-time jazz great Billie Holiday with a white gardenia pinned to his lapel by a 1968 Cartier Collection brooch featuring a ruby-eyed, yellow gold rabbit in a top hat. “It’s an Easter egg,” he said. But his saxophone proved his most important accessory, as Batiste proceeded to turn the Met Gala red carpet into an impromptu, headline-makingconcert. “To really pay homage properly, [a performance] needed to happen,” he said. Andra Day Batiste also greetedAndra Daywith zeal, as the star ofThe United States vs. Billie Holidayexcitedly told him she had brought visionary fashion futurist, designer, and consultantJérôme LaMaar“out of retirement” for her hot pink tuxedo. “[LaMaar] was the epitome of Black dandyism, Afrocentrism and Afro-futurism,” said Day. “I have been trying to get him to work with me for over 10 years.” The interview paused for a moment as Day’s stylist,Wouri Vice,and staffers buzzed around her, attempting to bustle the jacket’s long, bead-embellished train in preparation for the rainy commute to The Met. “The train pays homage to the dandy-ette,” said Day, explaining that it flowed out into three tobacco-leaf shapes. “Because we wanted to talk about the history—how we got to dandyism and what we had to break through to get there—and just remember how hard-fought and well-earned it was.” A self-professed admirer of the Cartier Panthère collections, Day proudly showed off jewelry conveying the spirit of Afro-futurism: an 18k white gold, diamond, emerald, and onyx bracelet; and two glittering rings, a geometric one and another of embracing felines. She also carried a Cartier leather clutch, encrusted with amethysts, hessonite garnets, and green onyx cabochons. “No one’s ever seen this before,” said Day, as a staffer brought over her phone—which was too big for the case. “It’s the first time it’s been debuted.” Another Simple Favoractor and haute horlogerie aficionadoHenry Goldingalso happily took a rare Cartier piece out for a test-spin. “I actually requested this watch. I’m a huge fan,” he said, showing the gleaming 18k yellow gold and black leather Cartier Tank à Guichets on his wrist. “It’s a dream watch.” Henry Golding For his third Met Gala, Golding earnestly dressed on theme in a custom gold three-piece suit, with Adinkra symbols signaling knowledge, by British Ghanaian Savile Row designerOzwald Boateng. “[Boateng] says that I wear and carry wisdom very well, so he designed the gold and the emblems,” said Golding, also emphasizing the connection to the zoot suit, a representation of pride and identity with roots in the Harlem Renaissance of the ’20s and ’30s. “It’s an honor to be able to represent someone like Oswald and be one of his muses for the evening.” Fellow Brit andWhite LotusbreakoutAimee Lou Woodwas one of the later arrivals to the pre-party—readying for her first Met Gala experience. Also in a version of black suiting, she quickly fell into animated conversation with Edebiri, as Bemelmans Bar longtime pianistEarl Roseplayed upbeat tunes as their backing track. “I’ve felt like for years I was always putting really girly clothes [on], and it’s not very me,” said Wood. “When [I found out the theme was] tailoring, I was like, ‘This is just the perfect moment right now.’” She happily found an exuberant custom Ahluwalia take on a tuxedo: a cropped jacket, shirt, and tie layered over a draped asymmetrical dress. After meeting designerPriya Ahluwaliaat a party, Wood knew the British Indian Nigerian designer would be her number one ask for her Met Gala debut. In collaboration with Wood’s stylist,Felicity Kay,Ahluwalia designed the tuxedo, inspired by the self-expressive, sharply outfitted, and resistance-fightingCongolese Sapeurs. The handmade flower appliqués on Wood’s ankle socks showcased Ahluwalia’s Nigerian and Indian roots. “It was just the perfect alignment,” said Wood, who adorned the jacket with an elegant Cartier Collection white gold and diamond brooch, circa 1939 Paris. Wood, feeling somewhat jittery about walking the red carpet, found relief in knowing herSex EducationcostarNcuti Gatwawas on the guest list. “He’s gonna be here, which is the best. It’s also the perfect theme for him, like he’s such a dandy,” said Wood. “And thenPatrick[Schwarzenegger], who’s inThe White Lotuswith me. So I’ve got two great [friends] and thenWalton[Gogginsis] here as well, somewhere.” Schwarzenegger—in pinstripe Balmain—considerately dropped into Bemelmans to hang with Wood, and chatted with Edebiri by the bar. Then the two costars left to share a ride to The Met, with Schwarzenegger presumably giving Wood pointers from the two previous times he attended (in2019with modelTaylor Hill,and in2022holding a red straw hat). Joe Burrow Wood wasn’t the only newbie at the Cartier pre-party. Cincinnati Bengals quarterbackJoe Burrowwas also getting in the zone, per se, at Bemelmans. “I’m a little out of my element, but I’m excited to experience something new, for sure,” said the athlete, also known asJoe Brrdue to his affinity for opulent jewelry (i.e., “ice”). “I just think the more that I can diversify that part of my life, the more well-rounded I’m gonna be.” Burrow also ventured into new territory with an Art Deco–style Cartier High Jewelry platinum pin with sizable pink and blue sapphires surrounded by diamonds. “I’ve never worn a brooch before, but this one just caught my eye with the colors and the shapes,” he said, also highlighting a relatively understated Les Berlingots de Cartier 18k yellow gold and snakewood necklace, a notable 18k yellow gold Cartier Santos-Dumont watch, and blue Panthère de Cartier sunglasses tucked into the pants pocket of his Gucci suit. “It’s all just about individual expression, and I like colors, I like blue, I like classy, and this fit exemplifies that,” said Burrow, also focusing on the most significant part of the evening. “Just celebrating African American history and culture is important to everybody in this country.” Appropriately,Dapper Dan,groundbreaking Harlem fashion designer and godfather of hip-hop fashion, was the last to appear, and quickly jetted off to The Met. He made his much-anticipated grand entrance in his own design, of course: a black-and-white, zoot-suit-inspired tuxedo with lace, honoring the Harlem Renaissance of the ’20s. “I tried to have my outfit embody the whole history,” said the Met Gala host committee member. “[The Harlem Renaissance] is the most important period to me—the true, liberating period of dandyism, because that’s when the grassroots people dressed themselves.” Dapper Dan The Harlem-based designer broke ground in fashion and culture by combining Western European luxury logos with bold streetwear—only to first be appropriated by those very fashion houses, and then to ultimately partner with Gucci and then creative directorAlessandro Michelein 2017. “I am regarded as the father of logo mania, and I wanted to tie in the history of Africa and history of the world to that in the diaspora,” he continued, referring to the Ghanaian Sankofa symbols, meaning “retrieve,” emblazoning his jacket and hat. Dapper Dan’s 18k yellow gold, peridot, and onyx Panthère de Cartier ring spoke to Cuba’s storied Leopard Society, and the pyramid-shaped yellow gold and diamond Cartier Collection ring, dating to 1932 New York, evoked Southern Gothic author Flannery O’Connor’s short story collectionEverything That Rises Must Converge. “Everything that rises must converge, and so I see myself coming together in Africa, here, the diaspora, everywhere,” said Dapper Dan, whose mink-collar, Louis Vuitton–logo, leather jacket “knock-up”—made for Run-DMC’s Jam Master Jay—is on exhibit at the Costume Institute. But the rose-shaped, 1936 New York–originated Cartier Collection brooch, sparkling with platinum, diamonds, and sapphires, sent the most celebrated message of the evening. “I suggested this here because of the flower,” said Dapper Dan. “Everybody’s happy that I’m finally getting my flowers.” See All the Fashion, Outfits, and Looks From the2025 Met Gala Red Carpet Hawk TuahOpens Up About Her Crypto Scandal Plus, Who MadeVF’s Met GalaBest-Dressed List? title: How Simone Biles and Jonathan Owens Turned the Met Gala 2025 Into the Best—and Best-Tailored—Date Night of All Time
article_text: On Tuesday, gymnastSimone Bilesand Chicago Bears safetyJonathan Owensare celebrating their second wedding anniversary, which made Monday’sMet Gala 2025the perfect site for an unforgettable date night. Biles, the most decorated US Olympic gymnast in history, has walked the carpet in the past, but 2025 marked Owens’s debut. To celebrate, the couple wore downright regal custom outfits, hers from Harbison Studio and his from Nigerian brand Deji & Kola, which they paired with complementary watches from Audemars Piguet. “The first year [of marriage], we were actually long-distance. The second year, being together for the most part has been really special because we didn’t get that first year together,” Biles toldVanity Fairas the couple prepared for the big night. “It’s just being in each other’s presence one day at a time, and just enjoying and embracing the moments that we do have together, because we are so busy and our schedules never really come together to do events like this. So we’ve been super lucky this week to do the Kentucky Derby and now the Met Gala together.” Owens and Biles were both excited aboutthe theme of this spring’s Costume Institute exhibition, “Superfine: Tailoring Black Style,” andthe night’s dress code, Tailored for You. “It’s so cool to be able to have the opportunity to attend this one,” Biles said. “As soon as the theme came out, I said, ‘I wanna go to that one so bad!’” Owens said his white suit was inspired by the Black history on display in the show. “I’m just putting the emphasis on fine tailoring and Black excellence,” Owens said of his look. “It’s a bit of a modern take on the Harlem Renaissance. I have fringe on the end of my hands and on my feet, so it just gives a very royal look.” He said he was also looking forward to seeing how others would interpret the theme. “I’m excited to seeColman Domingotonight. He truly embodies dandyism year-round, and I’m looking forward to seeing what he wears on fashion’s biggest night.” Before hitting the carpet, Biles said she was most excited by the color of her taffeta minidress with a cathedral-length train, which featured intricate metallic floral embroidery and 3D appliqué, as well as a pearl-colored satin collar. Harbison Studio, a brand founded by designerCharles Harbisonin 2013, described the color as capri blue, and Biles noted its similarity toone recent viral object. “My color is very vibrant. It’s just a very bright blue,” she said. “It’s like the Saratoga water bottle!” Biles accessorized with a matching pair of Aquazzura platforms and an Audemars Piguet Royal Oak Mini featuring a frosted gold case and bracelet. “Mine is obviously petite, packed with a punch, and I feel like that’s a great representation of myself and my personality,” Biles said of the timepiece. “So that’s why I love it.” Owens complemented his wife’s look with a couple blue accessories of his own, including a Margot McKinney Atlantic pendant, which featured a pearl drop and a 119-carat aquamarine surrounded by diamonds. His Royal Oak Perpetual Calendar was stainless steel with tone-on-tone blue dials. Biles said she was eagerly anticipating catching up with friends and fellow OlympiansSerena WilliamsandMiles Chamley-Watson.“I’m always excited to see Serena, just because I love her and we are always having good chitchat,” she said. “As well as Miles. We’re pretty good friends.” (Naturally, all three of them, plus Owens, werephotographed together inside the event, with Biles and Williams appearing deep in conversation.) Even though it was going to be Owens’s first time at the Met Gala, he said he was feeling calm, while Biles said she was panicked. “I just get so anxious about getting there,” she said. “I think it’s the same in gym. Like, I don’t panic that much, but I just get super nervous. But then, as soon as I raise my hand to salute and step onto the floor, or get out of the car and step onto the red carpet, I’m calm and everything is seamless.” This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. title: Behind the Scenes of Instagram’s Met Gala 2025 Class Photo With Nicki Minaj, Charli XCX, Shaboozey, Rosé, and More
article_text: Before taking to the iconic steps leading up to the Metropolitan Museum of Art Monday night for the2025 Met Gala, nine VIPs made their way through the dimly lit halls of the Mark Hotel to check off one last crucial bit of preparation: Posing for Instagram’s annual class photo. The portrait commemorates the celebrity guests invited to sit at Instagram’s table at the fête, and necessitates transforming one of the Mark’s luxe suites into an elaborate set tucked away behind stage curtains. This year’s celebrity guests posed for photographerQuil Lemonsindividually, then flagged their favorite shots, which were then edited together for a group photo nobody would dream of untagging. Head of InstagramAdam Mosseriwas first on set for the evening’s shoot, where he posed with his wife,Monica,and reflected on the platform’s nine-year partnership with the Met Gala. “We’re a place for creatives to express themselves and tell their stories, and fashion is one of the most important verticals for us. And so we’re excited to support the night, be part of it, but also just seeing what everybody brings,” he toldVanity Fair. As for who Mosseri was most looking forward to seeing on the Met Gala red carpet? Co-chairLewis Hamilton.“I’ve seen him rock some pretty amazing tuxes and a skirt in previous years. So my guess is he’s going to bring it,” he said. Eva Chen,VP of Fashion Partnerships at Meta, made a grand entrance into the suite, sparkling in a pale pink custom Wiederhoeft gown made of 370,000 glistening glass beads from Mumbai, which also featured matching beaded opera gloves with custom touch-screen fingertips. Having been “dazzled” by designerJackson Wiederhoeft’s talent, Chen turned to the popular bridal designer to make her custom corset creation. “When thinking about the theme of the Met Gala and your particular dandism, I thought no one would be able to channel that more than Jackson and their flair for corsets. It’s my first time wearing a corset,” she admitted. “My goal is to not faint, but I feel extremely comfortable, actually. We’re going to sit.” As Chen exited the set, she ran intoJeff Goldblumand his wife,Emilie,as they entered the room. “Now that’s what I call a train,” theWickedstar said of Chen’s billowing silk train. The actor easily exuded the Met Gala 2025 theme, Tailored for You, in his midnight blue Wales Bonner suit that he paired with a blue suede loafer version of Carrie Bradshaw’s favorite Hangisi crystal–embellished Manolo Blahniks, and a Mongolian cashmere coat with a cream shearling collar. But, of course, the Wizard of Oz had one more thing up his sleeve—a blinged-out Jacob & Co. diamond watch. “Feast your eyes upon that,” he said, noting that the glittering accessory was an ode to the late André Leon Talley, who wore a similar Jacob design. When asked who theJurassic Parkactor was excited to see this year, he recalled the 2024 Met Gala with hisWickedcostarsCynthia ErivoandAriana Grande.“I was here last year for the first time, and they were here. We had a moment of connection, and then they performed…I was crying big tears. You know, just ‘Somewhere Over the Rainbow’—but they did a great thing—both of them.” And while many stars celebrated their return to the Met steps,Shaboozeywas excited to make his Met Gala debut. “I’m so ready to get to the carpet,” the Grammy-nominated singer said in between shoots, while showing off his custom Robert Wun look. The black, wood-grain patterned suit was adorned with nearly 3,000 Swarovski turquoise beads, making for a bold pop of color. The county star went on to explain that he was inspired by the history of West Africa and his home state of Virginia for the unique design, which he topped off with a saucer-style hat and matching turquoise grill. “I’m a huge fan of turquoise, which is very Southwestern, you know. So we just tried to include as much turquoise as we could, keep certain things natural,” said theCowboy Cartercollaborator. “It really feels like West African as well, which I think there’s like a little bit of correlation that just shows like the history of West Africa and coming to America; it’s all embedded in all of these different cultures.” In honor of this year’s Met theme,Taraji P. Hensonchanneled her “divine dandy” with a bespoke collaboration fromMONSEandPost-Imperial, founded by Nigerian designerNiyi Okuboyejo.A few days before the gala, Henson celebrated her Met collaboration with cocktails at Monse’s Lower East Side store, where she joked that, though she hadn’t seen the creation, she wasn’t at all worried about her custom look. While standing in the bespoke outfit at the Mark on Monday, the sentiment remained. “I’m very happy with how it turned out,” she said of the all-white design, which featured a collared, corseted shirt dress with a tails-style jacket and no pants. “I was like, ‘leave the pants to the fellas.’ I want to be a toss-up of masculinity and femininity. I love it,” she said about her ensemble, which she accessorized with a white, pearl-handle cane and a matching bowler hat that she clarified was “just a prop.” Meanwhile, on the other side of the suite,Jenna Ortega’s shoot was underway as she posed in a striking Balmain gown made of metal rulers and tape stitched together, mimicking shimmering metallic chain mail. The young star, who swapped out herWednesdaypersona for old Hollywood glam, jingled as she moved through the set—her excitement matched by the echoing sound as she clapped and cheered when her session wrapped. While exiting the Instagram suite, Ortega greeted superstar singerRoséas she made her way inside. “I’m such a big fan,” Rosé said to theBeetlejuice Beetlejuiceactor, who smiled and returned the compliment before the singer headed onto the set. Charli XCXandNicki Minajrounded out the evening, arriving in the photo studio around 7 p.m. Despite coming off a four-day takeover of Brooklyn’s Barclays Center for the close of her US Brat Tour, the “365” singer appeared fresh and ready to go as she entered the Instagram suite, cheerfully greeting everyone. But leave it to Minaj to turn the last shoot of the night into a grand finale with a showstopping Thom Browne gown. Though it was hard for the singer to walk in the ultra-fitted, pinstripe suit dress, it only took a second for the photographer to exclaim, “We got the shot!” after Minaj immediately nailed her pose in true superstar fashion. title: Damson Idris on What It Took to Pull Off the Met Gala 2025’s Biggest Red-Carpet Reveal
article_text: “It makes me feel like I’m walking with the DNA of my forefathers,” actorDamson IdristellsVanity Fairof this year’sMet Gala theme.“When you see a dandy, you see history, but at the same time, you see innovation. You see confidence, but at the same you see vulnerability. And you see everything that that person and the culture has been through. It was the suits that my mother put me in for my birthday, or seeing Sidney Poitier inGuess Who’s Coming to Dinner—and then dandyism. All of that linked together is what makes me the man I am today,” he says, “and the taste I have when it comes to putting on a tailored suit.” Idris, who stars in the upcomingsummer blockbusterF1alongsideBrad Pitt,Kerry Condon, andJavier Bardem, describes working on the movie as the “most fun he’s ever had.” And art imitated life last night, as Idris arrived via anAPXGP carfrom the film, wearing a white racing suit and racing helmet covered in Swarovski crystals.On the carpet,Idrisunveiled the outfitunderneath the suit: a supremely tailored rouge tuxedo, with a contemporary nod toTommy Tartan. Both the racing suit and the tuxedo were designed by American iconTommy Hilfiger. The joint forces of Idris and Hilfiger were a match made in tailoring (and race car) heaven. The relationship between the actor and the designer began almost three years ago, when they met in Miami at an F1 event hosted by Hilfiger, who is also the official fashion sponsor of the upcoming film. For Idris, wearing the brand to the Met Gala was even more personal. He remembers Tommy Hilfiger being one of the first brands he bought when he was “making a little bit of money.” Understanding the assignment for this evening, designer Hilfiger began working on this year’s look the moment the theme was announced. “We wanted to reach back into the Tommy Hilfiger DNA,” Hilfiger says. “There’s a satin lapel that brought classic elegance to it. And the inner lining is the Ithaca stripe. The look was completed with tailored tuxedo pants featuring a side satin stripe and a flare at the knee to sort of give a nod to modern dandyism.” On the tartan side, 80 hours-worth of gold beading contrast against the special print (on the official Scottish Register of Tartans,) along with custom buttons that allowed for the actor to accomplish the theme with grace, style, and a twist on classic American tailoring. But Idris didn’t stop there. He also chose pieces from his newly launched jewelry brand, DIDRIS. The inspiration behind building the brand, he says, started roughly two years ago, during the Hollywood strikes; citing his mom’s love of jewelry as inspiration, he says he wanted to build a legacy that she could be proud of. “This space of fine jewelry is one that people like us don’t usually exist in,” he says, “so there was that challenge too. Me and my team created this custom brooch, which has green tourmaline, tsavorite, and an 11-carat emerald.” Green, he says, is “my favorite color on jewelry.” Besides the gems and the fine stitching, Idris’s essentials for pulling off his look are sleep and starting the day off with a long shower while Fela Kuti’sBeasts of No Nationis playing. “Between the release of this new picture that I’m in and just the [Met Gala] theme, I really wanna take it in, be present, and be focused,” he says. “I’m just excited [to see] everyone who’s smiling. title: Dapper Dan On the Symbolism Behind His Met Gala 2025 Look
article_text: Even at 80,Dapper Danremains a lifelong student. “All through the night, I watched documentaries on things that I want to talk about while I’m on the red carpet,” he toldVanity Fairshortly before attendingthe Met Gala 2025to celebrate the opening of the Costume Institute’s new exhibit, “Superfine: Tailoring Black Style.” This included a documentary on the groundbreaking Black actress Dorothy Dandridge, and footage of her performing the song “Zoot Suit” alongside Paul White in 1942. Dapper Dan at The 2025 Met Gala Celebrating "Superfine: Tailoring Black Style" held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on May 05, 2025 in New York, New York. For the exhibition’s theme, focused on the history and transforming contexts of Black dandyism, the designer, whose own work appears in the show, explained how he wanted his look to reference the zoot suits of the Harlem Renaissance. “The zoot suit symbolizes the freedom that we have associated with the dandy,” he said. Representing Harlem, where he’s lived formost of his life,was an especially personal directive too. In 1982, he opened his haberdashery shop Dapper Dan’s Boutique on 125th Street, where his signature“knock-ups”(one-of-a-kind garments featuring remixed luxury logos like Louis Vuitton and Gucci) became iconic pieces of their own.LL Cool J, Bobby Brown, Mike Tyson,and members of Run DMC were among his clientele. A trademark infringement lawsuit forced him to shutter the business in 1992, but in 2017, a surprising turn of events—Gucci acknowledged being influenced by one of Dapper Dan’s own designs—led to a collaboration and thereopening of his atelierin 2018. That year also marked Dapper Dan’s first Met Gala appearance and his shift from fashion outsider to a widely recognized cultural figure. Dapper Dan at The 2025 Met Gala Celebrating "Superfine: Tailoring Black Style" held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on May 05, 2025 in New York, New York. For this year’s Met Gala, Dapper Dan used an actualzoot suitfrom the Harlem Renaissance era as a model to fashion his own entirely sequin-covered version, featuring both aSankofa symbolin tiny print and a large Sankofa emblem of a bird with its head turned backward adorning the back of his jacket. “The symbol means ‘Go back to get.’ Go back and get so we can go forward. If we all go back first, we can come together,” he said. As though the all-sequined ensemble didn’t require enough heavy lifting up the Met’s red-carpeted steps (“Itisheavy,” he acknowledged), there was also a suite of Cartier jewelry to layer on, starting with a pyramid-cut diamond pinky ring that reminded the designer of his neighborhood’s early Italian presence. “During the Harlem Renaissance period, one of the biggest influences that a lot of people don’t realize were the Italians in Harlem,” he said. “We had the San Gennaro festival.” Dapper Dan's jewelry details There was also a multi-strand gold chain necklace—a nod to the Latinos and West Indians in the neighborhood—a bejeweled flower brooch, a gold pocket watch, and a signature Cartier panther ring that was an especially noteworthy addition to the ensemble’s various cultural references: “The panther is symbolic to the music that came out of the Congo, that went through Cuba, that was responsible for Afro-Cuban jazz.” While Dapper Danhad outfittedother celebrities for the Met Gala on past occasions, he was his sole client this year, instead opting to preserve his creative stamina. “I don’t want to leak out any energy. It takes something out of me, and it takes something out of the people who I dress,” he said. But that only makes him more excited to see who shows up and turns out for the major occasion, especially with the show’s theme in mind. “It’s so important to people of color…. This one shouldn’t be just about being elegantly dressed or very superfly,” he said. As a member of the gala’s host committee this year, he said he plans to hold guests accountable too. “This is a Cinderella event…. So, I mean, put your glass slippers on, and let’s get busy.” This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. title: Pamela Anderson on Being “Brave” at the Met Gala 2025, Debuting a Rebellious New Haircut on the Red Carpet, and Who Sat at Her “Power Table”
article_text: “For me, I could have jumped out of the shower and put the dress on and went to The Met,”Pamela Anderson,who attendedthe Met Gala 2025withTory Burch,said with a chuckle over the phone the morning afterfashion’s biggest night out. “The few people that came by my room said, ‘This doesn't feel likea Met [Gala]day. This is the quietest, most peaceful place,’” she toldVF.“I just keep it simple.” Over the last few years, the 57-year-old actor has made it her signature to do more with less on the red carpet, trading her iconic blond bombshell persona for a more minimal, stripped-back version of herself. And Monday night, her second-ever Met Gala, was no exception. Anderson glowed with minimal glam, allowing her custom, sculptural, icy blue Tory Burch gown to do all the talking as she appeared to float up the steps of The Metropolitan Museum of Art. “I feel like this is one of the great things about being my age and where I’m at in my life is that I’m not craving that attention. I’m not craving that scene. I’ve done it and I’ve done it with really wild, wonderful artists and people. I’ve had an interesting, messy life,” she said. “I’ve learned that I’m okay just the way I am and I’ll present myself the way I want to, not under any pressure, and I don’t worry if everybody’s going to like it.” It’s a confidence and freedombefitting of the Met Gala’s dress code, Tailored for You,in support ofthe Costume Institute’s spring exhibition, “Superfine: Tailoring Black Style,”and an aura Burch brought to life in Anderson’s simple yet strong silhouette that resembled a suit of armor. “I just loved the theme so much because I felt like it was like you need to be courageous and brave and precise in how you present yourself to the world and in how you find joy in fashion and confidence,” she said. Though Anderson has adopted a more relaxed approach to these larger-than-life events, months of preparation and craftsmanship went into making her gown. Burch first sent Anderson a sketch while she was filmingKornél Mundruczó’s upcoming film,Place to Be,in Australia, followed by multiple fittings to get the tailoring just right. Sparing no detail, the silk mesh gown was custom-made for Anderson from the inside out using traditional menswear techniques, with hand-sculpted boning, an exaggerated hip, and a molded floating neckline. To give it that effervescent sparkling effect, the gown was then embroidered with twisted silver sequins and crystals in Italy and finally constructed at Burch’s atelier in New York. “It’s actually sitting next to me on the couch right now and it pretty much looks the same off me as it does on me,” she remarked. “It looks like there’s a person in it without a head. It’s really very structured. It’s a sculpture.” Because of the higher floating neckline, Anderson immediately knew that the dress called for a haircut. A self-proclaimed rebel who has embraced this new season of life and period of self-discovery, Anderson didn’t hesitate to make the chop, debuting a whimsical bob with fringe on the carpet. “I am just being a brave little girl. Like the haircut—I had this haircut at five years old. When I did it, I was like, Oh my gosh, this looks like my kindergarten picture,” she said with a laugh. Reinventing herself—while shattering people’s expectations—whether that be on the red carpet or in new and exciting roles, such as last year’sThe Last Showgirland in her upcoming slate of projects, has become Anderson’s new superpower. “I’m not married to any style, and I think that this part of my life is all about freedom and making the choices I want to make. I don’t have a jury around me to tell me what to do, what to look like, how to dress and how to wear my hair,” she said. “So it’s always a collaboration, but I like that I can do whatever I feel. I don’t need to have my long hair. I don’t need to hide behind my hair or feed into a caricature, even though this kind of became a character. I just always do that. I just kind of go from character to character, which is, in a way, just trying to find yourself.” Ever evolving but always grounded by her roots, Anderson’s jewelry for the evening, a sparkling and sprawling ear cuff from Pandora, for which she is an ambassador, was actually a callback to her Met Gala debut last year. “What’s really wonderful about Pandora is that they love to repurpose, recycle, and they put a lot of thought into sustainability,” she said. “I was able to use my first Met necklace and make it into this ear cuff, and also give [her son]Brandon [Lee]a brooch. We used the same diamonds, and it’s just really kind of a clever way to keep using what you have.” Though Anderson admits that attending the Met Gala for the second year in a row doesn’t make it any less intimidating, she did feel more relaxed this time around. Having thrived through awards season, where she received a Screen Actors Guild and Golden Globe nomination for her performance inThe Last Showgirl,she felt more familiar with the landscape. “This time I was with Brandon, which always makes me feel more comfortable,” she said. “It was kind of a nice Mother's Day experience with Tory and I having our sons there.” She also credits the ease of the evening to her tablemates, likeJeremy O. Harris,Rashid Johnson,andJanicza Bravo,whom Burch also hosted. “We had such a fun power table, and everybody was so inspiring. It felt like a magical night. It really felt very relaxed and very fun and also very peaceful,” she said. “I can’t compare it to anything. There were a lot of synchronicities kind of going on. It really was beautiful. I think that everybody was in the same headspace. It just felt very, very collaborative and a lot of camaraderie.” She admits that after her son dropped her off at the hotel, she was in bed by 11 p.m., though she was still suffering from jet lag after traveling to New York from Australia. On Tuesday morning, she was awake at 5 a.m. and took a walk in Central Park to visit a tree that she adopted back in 2022. “It’s very grounding,” she said. It’s a quiet moment that will become increasingly rare for Anderson in the year ahead as she juggles several projects. Having just wrappedPlace to Bein Australia, she will spend the summer returning to the stage in a Williamstown Theatre Festival Production ofCamino Realby Tennessee Williams, promoting another upcoming film,Naked Gun,between shows, and then heading off to take on the lead role inSally Potter’sAlma. “Sally Potter is every actor’s dream. She is an incredible actor’s director, and I can’t wait to collaborate with her, especially right after coming off of Tennessee Williams’s play. I feel like I’m just learning. I’m soaking everything in a sponge and just really working hard, and it’s really fun,” said Anderson. “You never know how long this will last, so I’m just going to keep on working as hard as I can. This has all been a very mysterious and happy surprise that I didn’t expect at this time in my life. Not too many people get second chances like this, so I’m not taking it for granted.” After her big night out in the city and before her career kicks back into high gear, Anderson is eager to return to her happy place, her property on Vancouver Island in rural Canada, and get her hands dirty. “I have to finish planting my garden,” she said excitedly. “This is the most beautiful time of year. All the dogwoods are blooming, my tulips, the daffodils, my peonies. I just can’t wait to get into my garden, and I also have to finish planting my vegetables. I’m putting in a greenhouse this year, so it’s really exciting. That is my real love, and I feel so grounded and connected there. And then I go off into the world.” “You really have to have someplace as your sanctuary to feel grounded. And then you go off into these film projects and theater, and this is a really incredible time,” she said. “My kids are grown. I have no other distractions in my life personally. My relationship is to my work, and I’m enjoying it, and I’m really getting to know myself in the process, which is: I always knew that I could do more, that I was capable of more, and I still don't know what I made of. I feel like I’ve just scratched the surface.” All the Unforgettable Highlights From the2025 Met Gala See All the Fashion, Outfits, and Looks on theMet Gala Red Carpet Plus, Who MadeVF’sBest-Dressed List? title: Taraji P. Henson Didn't See Her Look Until the Day Before the Met Gala 2025—and Made One Big, Perfect Change
article_text: ForTaraji P. Henson,going to theMet Galareally is about what happens inside. “I am a nerd and I love art,” theactortoldVanity Fairbefore she hit the red carpet. “Every time I go to The Met, I’m always blown away by the art pieces that they pick to exhibit, so I can’t wait to go to see the exhibit. That’s my favorite part of the night.” Henson’s look forthe Met Gala 2025was created by Monse in collaboration with Post-Imperial, a brand founded by their former employee,Niyi Okuboyejo.To design her look for the night, a white suit jacket and bodysuit combo, they drew from a specific historical reference,a 1974 painting by Black painter Barkley Hendricks calledWhat’s Going On,which shows a variety of figures in white suits. Harding, who died in 2017, was known for portraiture that played with formal composition and put special attention on Black figures and self-presentation. In a statement, Monse explained that the look, which Henson paired with copper-colored pumps from Aquazzura, was intended to express a combination of masculinity and femininity. “It intertwines the craftsmanship of menswear with the daring spirit of Josephine Baker—a Divine Dandy embracing her Divine Femininity,” it read. “Each fabric weaves a narrative: The raw edges of the crisp cotton sateen and pique shirt float above a short pique corset dress, sculpting her silhouette, while an opulent wool silk coat envelops her in elegance, complemented by ethereal silk faille shawl lapels.” Henson has been working withstylist duoWayman+Micahfor years, and she said that they normally try to keep the look they’ve planned for the Met Gala a surprise until the final fitting. She loved the suit when she finally saw it, but in an interview conducted before Monday night's Met Gala, she explained how one final decision brought it to perfection. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity. Vanity Fair:How did the look come together? Taraji P. Henson:I didn’t see the look until yesterday at my fitting because Micah and Wayman, my stylists, wanted to keep it as a big surprise. I trust them, you know? They know me, they know my style, so we’ve been steadily telling a story in my fashion. And I love Monse. But when I saw it, I was just floored. Then I was, like, “I think the pants should go.” I wanted it to be a great cross between feminine and masculine, and I didn’t wanna cover all of my femininity up, so my suggestion was to lose the pants. When we took the pants off, everybody was, like, “This is the look.” I knew it was going to be guys doing the whole suit thing, so I just wanted to toss it up a bit. Besides, I worked really hard in the gym. We can’t cover up all my hard work. Is there anybody whose style you admire who you’re looking forward to seeing tonight? I cannot wait to seeRihanna!I can’t wait to see her andZendaya. I can’t wait to see the top ones, the ones that always shut down the carpet. I hope I’m one of them! Do you have any rituals before you go on a red carpet? I get lots of rest and drink lots of water. I do my meditation and prayer to keep me calm, and that’s about it. I’ll make sure I’m not eating things that are gonna bloat me—I haven’t had carbs in several days. I can’t wait to have a slice of pizza after the Met. I’m gonna have my driver take me straight to a pizza shop! I just want people to know that I am in a very peaceful place, where I have poured so much into myself. That’s why I’m glowing. Because I’m at peace. I love myself. I think I’m taking care of myself in a way that I never have in my life. I’m staying away from negative energy. Loving from afar, but protecting my peace at all cost. That’s what you’ll see on the carpet, a representation of my peace and joy that I found. This weekend, you were announcing a new mental health program in Prince George’s County, Maryland. What can you tell me about it? We are losing kids, and that’s what bothers me. Not too long ago, Prince George’s County lost an 11-year-old to suicide, and that really breaks my heart. As a mother, I can’t stand by idly and just do nothing. We are boots on the ground trying to get to these kids and meet them where they are. You know, you can’t say to a child you gotta get some therapy—they don't understand what that is. So we’re trying to implement fun activities for them, where they can decompress, then slip in therapy in there while they’re doing arts. We’re trying to implement our arts program and a facility where middle school students have somewhere to go after school. We need to pay attention to the middle schoolers. They have hormones kicking in and they’re trying to figure out who they are. They need a safe place to go after school where they can decompress and do some fun activities, like yoga, hip-hop therapy, arts and crafts, to activate their creative side. I think we can help and change those numbers. It’s all about meeting them where they are, and not talking past them or above them. Getting right to their level. title: Walton Goggins Felt “Like the Commander of the Death Star” Before Twirling Through His Met Gala 2025 Debut
article_text: A person never knows what version ofWalton Gogginsis going to walk into a room. The actor disappears into his roles so completely—donning tattered clothes and a decaying face asThe Ghoul inFallout,wrinkled Hawaiian shirts and melancholic vindictiveness asRick inThe White Lotus,and the big-haired, tile-toothed razzle-dazzle of theindelible Uncle Baby BillyinThe Righteous Gemstones,to name just three very recent examples—that it’s hard to put a finger on the guy underneath it all, let alone predict what he’d wear for hisMet Gala debut. Days prior, Goggins evenappeared on the cover ofCultured, knees spread, louche, wearing little more than an unbuttoned mustard shirt, a banana yellow Speedo, and a smirk. Speaking toVanity Fairfrom his hotel room Monday amid hisMet Gala 2025prep, he allowed that his customThom Brownelook—an ensemble worthy ofour best-dressed list—was “a little less revealing” than his cover wardrobe. “Slightly.” But not to worry: “I have yellow underwear, the yellow Speedo’s on underneath this.” “This,” it should be explained, was a bespoke suit made up of a sport coat, classic oxford shirt and tie, and ankle-length pleated skirt. This isn’t just a well-fitted suit: The whole look was made “inside out,” with visible tailoring hand stitches, exposed shoulder pads, and style lines standing out in bright contrast with the dark pin-striped wool suiting, double duchess silk, silk faille, and three-ply wool mohair of the ensemble, highlighting the immense effort and multitude of details that go into creating a perfectly tailored suit—tiny, hyper-personal intricacies that, deployed correctly, disappear behind the seams and become more than the sum of their parts. Needless to say, Goggins’s look, accessorized with David Yurman jewelry, rose to the challenge of the night’s dress code, Tailored for You, in celebration of the Costume Institute’s exhibit, “Superfine: Tailoring Black Style.” “Deconstructing a suit and then rebuilding it from the inside out is tantamount to really showing everything that is under your skin, how the body works,” Goggins said. “And this is like how the mind works in tailoring. So you’re just showing everybody how much work goes into this seamless presentation of the outer layer of this garment. I was just kind of blown away by that concept and here we are.” As a Thom Browne superfan, Goggins was ready to let the designer do pretty much whatever he wanted. He recounted his stylist,Erica Cloud,calling him a few weeks ago and asking him if he’d be willing to shift a scheduled trip to London to attend the Met Gala. “I thought, Oh, yeah, yeah. Who is it for? And then she said, ‘Are you ready for this?’ And I said, ‘Sure, I think I’m ready.’ She said, ‘Thom Browne.’ I said, ‘I’ve already changed my flight. I’ve canceled my flight.I have no flight.’ My relationship with Thom Browne goes back a very long way.” He traced the roots of his love affair with Browne’s work all the way back to being a broke actor wandering the aisles of Wilshire Boulevard department stores, touching fabric and trying on clothes that he couldn’t really afford. One day, he discovered something that helped him unlock his personal style philosophy, aiming for a look he describes as “devastatingly understated,” and “wearing everything with reverence, but as if you slept in it.” “I came across this one particular shirt that I tried on and it fit me as if I’d been wearing it my whole life, and it was one of the first shirts that I put on where I felt like, This is a true expression of who I am as a person.Thisis how I would dress. Who makes this? I looked at the label, and it was Thom Browne.” He saved up and bought one of those shirts, first in white, “because I could wear it anywhere, and then a blue one, because I could wear it anywhere, and then a light gray one, because I could wear it anywhere.” “That was almost 20 years ago, and I still have those shirts,” he said. The invisible thread connecting Goggins to the brand surfaced again at a photo shoot in Malibu a few years later: “I tried this jacket on, and it felt like it was mine, like, This is mine. Who makes this?” Again, “It was Thom Browne.” He begged the stylist on the shoot to let him take the jacket home with him, but was denied, as it was one-of-a-kind. Instead, he wrote Browne a letter saying how much he admired the jacket and loved his work. “A week later, I get a package in the mail with that jacket in it, and a note from Thom Browne saying, ‘Hope you enjoy it...’ His dot, dot, dot. And I put that note on my corkboard 18 years ago, and it’s still there,” he said. “What a wonderful human being to have done that so long ago.” He still has not only the note, but the jacket, and those first three shirts he scrimped and saved for. On Monday, giddy and running on a self-proclaimed four hours of sleep before the Met Gala, Goggins allowed himself to be talked into trying out an exuberant twirl that he would later display on the steps of The Met, warning, “We might need more room,” before handing his phone over to a friend and allowing the skirt to swirl around him. “How do I feel?” he mulled. “I feel like the commander of the Death Star. I feel like a dandy. I feel like a peacock. It makes me feel on the outside how I wake up every day feeling on the inside. Yeah, I feel special. But I’ve always felt that special wearing Thom Browne.” When he first tried on the look, he said, “I just kind of came alive. And [my stylist] Erica was watching on Zoom, and she said, ‘Oh, there it is. Okay, that’s it. That’s exactly how you wear it. That’s exactly how you’re supposed to feel.’” Goggins finds joy in experiences as varied as the roles he portrays in his projects, and the Met Gala is just one more first for him. “For me, this isn’t about ego,” he said. “For me, this isn’t about being invited to the club or being included at the dinner table. To me, this is an experience, and I live my life for an experience, and like with everything that has happened in my life—it’s like before working with [Quentin]Tarantino,after working with Tarantino, before going to India, and after going to India, before going to the Met Gala, and after going to the Met Gala. It’s an honor to be included, but moreover, it is an experience that I don’t imagine anyone that ever attends this event will ever forget.” “Here we go,” he said, drawing in a breath and grinning hugely again. “We’ll see what life is like on the other side of it.” For more from the Met Gala 2025, revisitVanity Fair’s Met Gala 2025 liveblogfor the evening’s highlights includingevery look, thebest-dressed of the night, our experts’ picks for whobest embodied the theme, avideo replay of the red carpet, and more. title: How RFK Jr. Is Already Undermining Vaccines Under Trump
article_text: During his confirmation hearing to become secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services,Robert F. Kennedy Jr.tried to distance himself from his notorious reputation as the country’s most infamous anti-vaxxer. He said he supported the measles vaccine,despite writingin a 2021 book that Americans had been “misled” into “believing that measles is a deadly disease and that measles vaccines are necessary, safe, and effective.” He promised to support the childhood vaccine schedule, despite casting doubt on the long-term safety of that schedulein his 2023 book. “I believe that vaccines play a critical role in healthcare,” Kennedy said. “All of my kids are vaccinated.” Kennedy’s doublespeak was at least enough to land him the job. Now that he’s in it, though, Kennedy has continued apace with his just-asking-questions approach to undermining vaccination in America. Kennedy’s attacks on vaccines were apparently so swift and so disruptive that in late March, the Food and Drug Administration’s top vaccine official quit the agency ina fiery resignation letter. “This man doesn’t care about the truth. He cares about what is making him followers,” Dr.Peter Markswrote to the FDA’s acting commissioner. Here’s a look at just some of the ways Kennedy is eroding vaccine trust from inside the government. Reviewing the childhood vaccine schedule Less than a week after his confirmation hearing, Kennedy delivered a speech to HHS staff in which he announced his department would investigate childhood vaccinations as part of a newly formed commission that President Trump created through an executive order. That commission,Kennedy said, would look into issues that “were formerly taboo or insufficiently scrutinized,” according toThe New York Times. “Nothing is going to be off limits,” Kennedy reportedly said. Kennedy is also reportedly consideringremoving the CDC’s COVID-19 recommendation for children, though an HHS spokesperson told Politico last month that “no final decision has been made.” Appointing an anti-vaxxer to lead a study on autism As HHS secretary,Kennedy has sought to discreditresearch from the Centers for Disease Control, which found that increases in autism diagnoses are largely due to broader screening and identification of people in “previously underidentified groups.” Instead, Kennedy claimed that “environmental” factors were to blame for this “epidemic” and commissioned a study to determine those supposed root causes. The tell is inwho he tapped to lead the study: anti-vaxx researcherDavid Geier.Geier, who was oncecharged with operating without a medical license, has written extensively about the supposed link between vaccines and autism,which has been repeatedly debunked. Kennedy, who isreportedly planninga national registry of autistic people as part of this research, has said he plans to have the initial results of the study by September. Cutting resources for vaccination In late March, theCDC withdrew$11.4 billion in funds for state and community health programs. That included roughly $2 billion in grants for “Immunization and Vaccines for Children,”according to NBC News. Staffing cuts across HHS, meanwhile, havehit vaccination programs hard, including in Texas, which has been at the center of the measles outbreak. On the other end of the spectrum, Kennedy has thwarted efforts to limit vaccine hesitancy. TheNational Institutes of Health has terminateddozens of research grants focused on vaccine hesitancy, according toScience. A letter sent to grant awardees reportedly stated, “It is the policy of NIH not to prioritize research activities that focus on gaining scientific knowledge on why individuals are hesitant to be vaccinated and/or explore ways to improve vaccine interest and commitment.” Mixed messaging on measles vaccination As the measles crisis in Texas grew,Kennedy acknowledgedon social media that “The most effective way to prevent the spread of measles is the MMR vaccine.” But that was only afterhe confused the messagein a Fox News interview, saying that it was difficult for measles to kill healthy people and suggested thatpoor nutrition and exercisecontributed to the outbreak in Texas. He also claimed—against evidence—that “natural immunity” to measles may be more beneficial than vaccination and thatcod liver oilwas among the natural treatments delivering “very, very good results.” Pushing changes to vaccine testing Just last week, HHS announced that all new vaccines would need to undergo placebo testing, which aspokesperson for the department toldThe Washington Postwas "a radical departure from past practices.” Which is true—but with good reason. Vaccines that have been around for a while—including COVID-19 boosters—are often not tested against placebos, in part because that would require depriving a subset of trial patients of a vaccine that's known to treat a deadly disease. Now, public health experts worry that Kennedy's new mandate, the details of which are still hazy, could stand in the way of the release of Covid boosters in the fall. “You are watching the gradual dissolution of the vaccine infrastructure in this country,” Paul Offit, director of the Vaccine Education Center at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, toldThe Post. “The goal is to make vaccines less available and less affordable.” See All the Fashion, Outfits, and Looks From the2025 Met Gala Red Carpet Hawk TuahOpens Up About Her Crypto Scandal Plus, Who MadeVF’s Met GalaBest-Dressed List?
